metadata.title: Early transmission dynamics and control of COVID-19 in a southern hemisphere setting: 1 Nombre E-mail Area

abstract.text: The COVID-19 pandemic that emerged in Wuhan China rapidly spread around the world. The 49 daily incidence trend has been rapidly rising in Latin America since March 2020 with the great 50 majority of the cases reported in Brazil (28320) followed by Peru (11475) as of April 15 th , 2020. 51 Although Peru implemented social distancing measures soon after the confirmation of its first case 52 on March 6 th , 2020, the daily number of new COVID-19 cases continues to increase. We assessed 53 the early COVID-19 transmission dynamics and the effect of social distancing interventions in 54 Lima, Peru. 55 56 We estimate the transmission potential of COVID-19, R, during the early phase of the outbreak, 57 from the daily series of imported and autochthonous cases by the date of symptoms onset as of 58 March 30 th , 2020. We also assessed the effect of social distancing interventions in Lima by 59 generating short-term forecasts grounded on the early transmission dynamics before interventions 60 were put in place. 61 62 Prior to the implementation of the social distancing measures in Lima, we estimated the 63 reproduction number at 2.3 (95% CI: 2.0, 2.5). Our analysis indicates that school closures and 64 other social distancing interventions have helped stem the spread of the virus, with the nearly 65 exponential growth trend shifting to an approximately linear growth trend after the national 66 emergency declaration. 67 68

The COVID-19 epidemic in Lima followed an early exponential growth trend, which slowed down 69 and turned into an almost linear growth trend after broad scale social distancing interventions were 70 put in place by the government. 71 72

body_text.text: The COVID-19 pandemic that emerged in the city of Wuhan in China in December 2019 (Nishiura, 81 Jung, et al., 2020) has invaded nearly every nation of the world (Mizumoto, Kagaya, & Chowell, 82 2020; Worldometer, 2020), becoming the most important public health emergency of the last 83 century after the 1918-1920 influenza pandemic. In particular, the novel coronavirus (SARS-CoV-84 2) has an ability to exert substantial severe disease and mortality burden especially among 85 individuals older than 60 years and those with prior health conditions including hypertension, 86 cardiovascular disease, obesity and diabetes (Adler, 2020; Team, 2020) . As of April 15 th , 2020, 87 the trajectory of the pandemic varies significantly around the world ranging from relatively 88 contained outbreaks in Thailand, Taiwan and Hong Kong to explosive epidemics characterized by 89 initial exponential growth periods in some hotspots in the United States and European countries 90 including Italy, Spain, UK, and France (Ebbs, 2020; Griffiths, 2020; Minder, 2020) . of COVID-19 cases in Peru, the government shuttered schools on March 11 th , 2020. The next day, 106 the government banned gatherings of more than 300 people and suspended all international flights 107 from Europe and Asia. On March 16 th , 2020, the government declared a national emergency and 108 closed country borders (Explorer, 2020) . Subsequently, on March 17 th , 2020 the president of Peru 109 . The copyright holder for this preprint this version posted May 5, 2020. . https://doi.org/10.1101/2020.04.30.20077594 doi: medRxiv preprint announced the beginning of community transmission of SARS-CoV-2 in the country, and ordered 110 a curfew in the region on March 18 th , 2020 to avoid night time socializing to prevent disease 111 transmission (Explorer, 2020; Writing, 2020) . 112

In order to combat the spread of the COVID-19 epidemic in Lima, the capital and largest city of 114 Peru, estimates of the transmission potential of COVID-19 can guide the intensity of interventions 115 including the reproduction number, R, during the early transmission phase (Nishiura & Chowell, 116 2009 . Moreover, using the epidemiological data and mathematical modeling, it is possible 117 to gauge the impact of control interventions including school closures and a national emergency

We generate short term forecasts in real time using the generalized growth model (GGM) that 133 relies on two parameters and characterizes the early ascending phase of the epidemic allowing to 134 capture a range of epidemic growth profiles including sub-exponential (polynomial) and 135 exponential growth. GGM characterizes epidemic growth by estimating two parameters (i) the 136 intrinsic growth rate, r and (ii) a dimensionless "deacceleration of growth" parameter, p. The latter 137 parameter modulates the epidemic growth patterns including the sub-exponential growth (p<1) 138 and exponential growth dynamics (p=1). The GGM model is given by the following differential 139 equation: 140 . Where C ' (t) describes the incidence over time t. The cumulative number of cases at time is given 142 by ( ) while is a positive parameter denoting the growth rate (1/time) and ∈[0,1] is a 143 "deceleration of growth" parameter (Chowell, 2017 ; Viboud, Simonsen, & Chowell, 2016). 144 145
We calibrate the GGM model to the daily case incidence by the date of symptoms onset for Lima. 147

The data by onset dates for Lima is available from February 29 th , 2020. Therefore, our model was 148 calibrated using case series from February 29 th -March 15 th , 2020, prior to the implementation of 149 national emergency in Lima. 150

The best fit model solution is estimated by using a non-linear least square fitting approach (full 152 details provided in (Chowell, 2017) ). This process searches for the set of model parameters that 153 minimizes the sum of squared differences between the observed data y 01 = y 02 , y 04 , … . y 07

We denote the local incidence at calendar time t 1 by I 1 , the incidence of imported cases at calendar 181 time t 1 by J 1 , and the discretized probability distribution of the generation interval by ρ 1 . In this 182 equation the numerator represents the total new cases I 1 , and the denominator represents the total 183 number of cases that contribute to the new cases I 1 at time t 1 . The relative contribution of imported 184 cases to the secondary disease transmission is represented by the parameter 0≤ α ≤ 1. We perform 185 a sensitivity analyses by setting α = 0.15 and α = 1.0 to assess the contribution of imported cases 186 to the secondary disease transmission (Nishiura & Roberts, 2010) . This is followed by the 187 derivation of the uncertainty bounds around the curve of R directly from the uncertainty associated 188 with the parameter estimates (r, p). We estimate R for 300 simulated curves assuming a Poisson 189 error structure (Chowell, 2017) . is the author/funder, who has granted medRxiv a license to display the preprint in perpetuity.

FIGREF1.text: 15 th , 2020, SARS-CoV-2 is generating local transmission in over 200 countries with over 93 2.2 million cases and 150 thousand deaths reported globally (WHO, 2020). The COVID-19 94 pandemic was confirmed to have reached Latin America in February 2020 with gradual expansion 95 in the region until March 2020 when the COVID-19 incidence curve started to grow more rapidly. 96 By April 15 th , 2020, the US still has the highest number of COVID-19 reported cases (637196) 97 globally whereas in Latin America, Brazil has reported the highest number of cases (28320) 98 followed by Peru (11475) (Worldometer, 2020). 99 100 Peru, a country located in western South America, reported its confirmed imported index case in 101 Lima on March 6 th , 2020, a Peruvian with a travel history to France, Spain and Chez Republic 102 (Aquino & Garrison, 2020). By April 15 th , 2020, a total of 11475 cases including 254 deaths have 103 been reported by the Peruvian government. Lima, the capital of Peru has the highest number of 104 COVID-19 reported cases (8412) within Peru (MOH, 2020). To respond to the growing number 105

FIGREF2.text: 118 declaration in Lima by assessing short-term forecasts grounded on the trajectory of the epidemic 119 prior to the implementation of control interventions (Funk, Camacho, Kucharski, Eggo, the daily number of COVID-19 confirmed cases by date of symptoms onset in Lima, 125 Peru by March 30 th , 2020. Individual-level case details including whether the case was locally 126 acquired or imported were also made available from the Centro Nacional de Epidemiología 127 Prevención y control de Enfermedades (CDC Perú) and the National Institute of Health of the 128 Ministry of Health, Peru. We also examined the daily testing rate and the positivity rate from the 129 daily number of positive and negative PCR test results until March 30 th , 2020. 130 131

Thus, the objective function for the best fit solution of f(condition is fixed to the first observation in the data. Next, we derive uncertainty around 161 the best fit model solution as well as the confidence intervals of the parameters utilizing a 162 parametric bootstrapping approach assuming a Poisson error structure as described in ref (4. Reproduction number from case incidence using the generalized-growth model 166 The reproduction number, R, quantifies the variation in the average number of secondary cases 167 generated by a primary case during the early ascending phase of an outbreak before the 168 implementation of interventions or behavior changes in a completely susceptible population 169 (Anderson & May, 1991; Chowell et al., 2015; Nishiura, Chowell, Heesterbeek, & Wallinga, 2010is declining (R<1). Therefore, it is imperative to maintain the R<1 to contain an 172 outbreak. The reproduction number is estimated by calibrating the GGM to the early growth phase 173 of the epidemic (16 days) (Viboud et al., 2016), using the information on the gamma distribution 174 of the generation interval of SARS-CoV-2 with a mean of 4.41 days and a standard deviation of 175 3.17 days (Nishiura, Linton, & Akhmetzhanov, 2020; You et al., 2020). Then we simulate the 176 progression of local incident cases by onset dates from the calibrated GGM model incorporating 177 the imported cases and apply the discretized probability distribution of generation interval using 178 renewal equation given as (Nishiura & Chowell, 2009, 2014; Paine et al., 2010): 179

FIGREF4.text: 1. COVID-19 testing rates and positivity rate 193 Figure 1 shows the daily number of positive and negative laboratory test results and the positivity 194 rate during March 4 th -March 30 th , 2020. The total number of PCR tests performed for this time 195 period were 11518 (1127 positive results and 10307 negative results). The average daily number 196 of PCR tests performed in Lima was estimated at ~188 between March 4 th -March 15 th , 2020 197 whereas the number of tests performed between March 16 th -March 30 th , 2020 increased to ~617 198 tests per day. Subsequently, the positivity rate (percentage of positive cases among the positive 199 and negative cases) has ranged from 0.6-23.9 % between March 4 th -March 30 th , 2020. 200 curve by the date of symptoms onset, stratified by the local and imported 203 incidence case counts is shown in Figure 2. On average ~6 imported cases and ~162 local cases 204 have been reported daily between March 16 th -March 30 th , 2020 in Lima. A total of 2783 205 autochthonous cases and 151 imported cases have been reported in Lima as of March 30 th , 2020. 206 207 3.3. Reproduction number, R 208 We estimated the reproduction number using the first 16 epidemic days prior to the implementation 209 of social distancing interventions which includes the national emergency declaration on March 210 16 th 2020. The local incidence curve by the date of onset displays near exponential growth 211 dynamics with the scaling of growth parameter, p, estimated at 0.Assessing the impact of social distancing interventions 217 In order to assess the impact of social distancing interventions in Lima, including school closures 218 on March 11 th , 2020 and the declaration of national emergency on March 16 th , 2020, we generate 219 a 20-day ahead forecast for Lima based on the daily incidence curve until the declaration of the 220 national emergency in Lima. The 16-day calibration period of the model yields an estimated 221 growth rate, r, at 0.8 ( 95%CI: 0.6, 1.1) and a scaling of growth rate parameter, p, at 0.8 (95%CI: 222 0.7,0.9). The 20-day ahead forecast suggests that the effect of the school closure and the national 223 emergency declaration slowed down the spread of the virus as shown in Figure 4. Indeed, the 224 scaling of growth parameter declined to 0.53 (95% CI: 0.48, 0.58), consistent with an 225 approximately linear incidence growth trend during the intervention period. estimates of the early transmission potential in Lima for the first 16 days of the 229 epidemic indicates sustained local transmission in the region after accounting for multiple case 230 importations with the estimate of reproduction number R at ~2.3 (95% CI: 2.0, 2.5) which is 231

FIGREF5.text: ; Wu, Leung, & Leung, 2020). In contrast, a recent study on Singapore's COVID-235 19 transmission reported a lower estimate of R at ~0.7, which has been explained as a result of the 236 implementation of a sweeping social distancing interventions.237 238 The initial scaling of growth parameter in Lima indicates a nearly exponential growth pattern, 239 consistent with the early spread of the COVID-19 epidemic in Iran and the exponential growth 240 pattern of COVID-19 displayed by the Chinese province of Hubei (Muniz-Rodriguez et al., 2020; 241 Roosa et al., 2020). In comparison sub-exponential growth patterns of COVID-19 have been 242 observed in Singapore (p~0.7), Korea (p~0.76) and other Chinese provinces excluding Hubei 243 (p~0.67) as described in recent studies (Roosa et al., 2020; Shim et al., 2020; Tariq et al., 2020). 244 245 Although Lima has been quick to take aggressive measures against COVID-19, Peru remains one 246 of the hardest hit countries in Latin America (Tegel, 2020). Despite the closure of country borders 247 on March 16 th , 2020 imported cases in Lima have increased with an average of ~6 imported cases 248 reported between March 16 th -March 30 th , 2020 in comparison to an average of ~4 imported cases 249 reported per day before March 16 th , 2020. As of April 2 nd , 2020, Peru has adopted the gender-250 based quarantine measures for a week, where men and women were assigned particular days of 251 the week to leave the house to buy groceries and medicine, in an attempt to further slow the spread 252 of COVID-19 in the region (Westcott et al., 2020). The 20-day ahead forecast of our GGM model 253 calibrated to 16 days suggest that the social distancing measures, including closure of schools and 254 the declaration of national emergency are helping slow down the virus spread in Lima. Moreover, 255 the scaling of growth parameter, p was estimated at ~0.5 (95%CI: 0.5,0.6) after the implementation 256 of social distancing measures, consistent with a linear incidence growth trend. However, the 257 COVID-19 case incidence continues to accumulate despite the quarantine and lockdowns in the 258 region highlighting the need to enhance social distancing measures to further contain the outbreak. 259 260 The average positivity rate of COVID-19 in Lima was ~8.6% between March 4 th -March 30 th , 2020. 261 This positivity rate for Lima, Peru, corresponds to the positivity rates derived from Denmark, 262

FIGREF6.text: . Moreover, there is a substantial fraction of asymptomatic COVID-19 cases, which could 266 have underestimated our estimates that relied on the daily incidence's growth trend from 267 symptomatic cases(Mizumoto, Kagaya, Zarebski, & Chowell, 2020; Wei et al., 2020). On the 268 other hand, it is not known up to what extent asymptomatic cases transmit the virus relative to 269 symptomatic cases. Our study underscores the need for active contact tracing efforts, isolation and 270 strict social distancing measures to contain the outbreak and mitigate active disease study we estimate the early transmission potential of SARS-CoV-2 in Lima, Peru. Our 275 current findings point to sustained transmission of SARS-CoV-2 in the early phase of the outbreak, 276 with our estimate of the mean reproduction number ~2.3. The COVID-19 epidemic in Lima 277 followed an early exponential growth trend, which slowed down and turned into an almost linear 278 growth trend (p~0.5) after broad scale social distancing interventions were put in place by the 279 government. While the interventions have slowed the virus spread, the number of new COVID-19 280cases continue to accumulate, highlighting the need to continue social distancing and active case 281 finding efforts to mitigate disease transmission in the region. .C. is partially supported from NSF grants 1610429 and 1633381 and R01 GM 130900. 293 ., C.V. and G.C. analyzed the data.
